Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Convergence Ecology - Research Experience for Undergraduates in Ecological Diversity across Systems and Disciplines
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site award has been made to Southern Illinois University (SIU) that will provide research training for 10 students for 10 weeks each summer during the summers of 2013- 2015. The program has a goal to provide students with hands-on training with a diversity of tools used to conduct ecological research across a spectrum of research areas (to include soil, plants, animals, and multiple ecosystems) and processes (ecological pattern and variability, ecological response to environmental degradation, ecological response to restoration, and conservation and management) through the diverse research programs of 12 faculty members affiliated with SIU?s Center for Ecology. The program will immerse students in research and educational activities aimed to foster (1) hands-on scientific inquiry (from observation through conclusion) by conducting a research project, (2) development of a diverse ecological skills-set through guided quantitative field and laboratory methods, (3) comprehension of and confidence in communicating science through weekly reading and discussion, (4) a broad awareness of ecological science through weekly seminars, and (5) a better understanding of biodiversity (to include human culture) through educational field trips to local natural and cultural areas. Students also will be trained in ethics, responsible conduct of research, and proper animal care and use. The program will culminate with The Colloquium of Undergraduate Research in Ecology ('The CURE'), a symposium of oral presentations delivered by REU students and other undergraduate researchers at SIU. The program's multi-phase recruitment effort consists of both traditional "hard copy" formats as well as digital-based advertising. Students are selected based on academic record, prior research performance, and potential for outstanding research in ecology. Students are tracked to determine their continued interest in their academic field of study, their career paths, and the lasting influences of the research experience. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including use of an REU common assessment tool. More information is available by visiting http://www.ecology.siu.edu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Clay Nielsen at kezo92@siu.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Sara Baer at sgbaer@siu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theme of our REU program in "Convergence Ecology” was a broad introduction to ecological research made possible from the diverse research programs among an interdisciplinary group of faculty at Southern Illinois University (SIU) and the geographically-unique region of southern Illinois. Our conceptual framework consisted of a matrix of faculty expertise in ecological focal areas and processes to demonstrate the breadth of ecological research that could be performed at SIU. The REU program consisted of Conducting a Research Project, Ecological Measurements, Ecology Interact Sessions, Seminar and Hour with an Ecologist, Regional Exploration of Diversity, and The CURE. We offered the 10-week summer program to 29 students in this 3-year period; all but one student completed the program (due to illness). In addition to faculty guided research, the REUs learned research skills during weekly meetings with a Graduate Assistant on the topics of searching scientific literature, structure of a research proposal, spreadsheets and analyzing data, graphing results, and developing presentations. Students also met weekly with the Graduate Assistant for progress reports.  

We drew on the diversity of expertise in ecology across departments and colleges at SIU and natural resource managers in the region to fulfill program activities. Ecological Measurements sessions were offered on the topics of introductory statistics, experimental design, wildlife ecology methods, fish ecology, quantifying plant diversity, classifying soil, stream bioassessment, measuring nutrients in soil, and stable isotope analyses. The Seminars and Hour with an Ecologist included time dedicated to discussing career options and applying to graduate school. Several faculty presented research on diverse topics. The SIU Graduate Dean spoke about careers and applying to graduate school. Two former REU students and graduate students from SIU, now in faculty and post-doctoral positions, spoke on how the REU program set their career paths. We also hosted speakers from agencies such as The Nature Conservancy, the Illinois Department of Natural Resources, and the Illlinois Invasive Species Strike Team to inform students of non-academic opportunities in the field. Students also participated in Regional Explorations of Diversity to the Cache River, and visited Garden of the Gods, Middle Mississippi River Wetland Field Station, Giant City State Park, Cahokia Mounds, and the Shedd Aquarium.

Each REU student conducted an independent research project that accompanied ongoing research in faculty participant labs, but were independent questions addressed by each REU. All students presented their research. Oral presentations were delivered in 2013 and posters in 2014 and 2015 to facilitate dissemination REU research. Out of the students participating in the REU program, >70% of students presented their REU research at their home institution and >7 projects were presented at meetings of scientific societies. One student first-authored a publication in Ecological Restoration, >12 manuscripts are in preparation for publication, and results from one project were cited in Ecology.
